body: A Brooklyn man defended himself and his girlfriend by shooting and killing a man who broke into their apartment on Sunday night, the police said. The couple were later arrested after the police found more than a pound of marijuana they said belonged to them. The couple, Sheldon Barrow and Beverly Seales, told the police they were home around 6:45
title: Killer of Intruder Held on Drug Charge

body: FEUERHERD--Lillian C. (Dolan) of Garden City, NY (native of Brooklyn, NY), age 73, on December 5, 2003. Wife for 53 years of Victor E. Feuerherd; mother of Victor of Madison, WI, Peter of Rego Park, NY; David of Los Angeles, CA; Joseph of Kensington, MD; Matthew of Gaithersburg, MD; Elizabeth Munafo of Jericho, NY; and the late Stephen and Mary.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths FEUERHERD, LILLIAN C. (DOLAN)

body: IN 1957, a 21-year-old medical student from Queens, Raymond V. Damadian, faced his regular doubles partner and close friend, Charles Bruckl, in the final round of a amateur championship tennis match at Forest Hills. Mr. Bruckl won, snaring the attention and opportunities that came with the title, including a plum summer job as a tennis pro in
title: L.I.@WORK; A Doctor's Quixotic Quest for a Nobel Prize

body: A Brooklyn Home For Feminist Art Like all museums, the Brooklyn Museum of Art is grappling with budget cuts. (It closed for two weeks in August, and each staff member was on furlough for at least a week.) But that hasn't stopped the museum from forging ahead with a $63 million capital project that includes a new front entrance and plaza scheduled
title: INSIDE ART

body: Finding London Apartments Q.I once stayed in a bedsit in London and would like to do so again on my next trip there. Are there organizations or Web sites to help find one? -- Lynn Aneis, Brooklyn, N.Y. A. A bedsit is generally a studio room with a shared kitchen and bathroom, says Paul Chibeba, a spokesman for VisitBritain, the national tourist
title: Q and A

body: In move that could prolong and complicate an already contentious bankruptcy case, creditors of Owens Corning, which was driven into Chapter 11 proceedings by asbestos lawsuits, are pressing for the removal of the presiding judge. Legal experts say the challenge by the creditors could be used to undermine the legitimacy of the judge's previous
title: Creditors Seek Judge's Removal In Asbestos Case

body: New York City voters overwhelmingly rejected a measure yesterday that would have instituted nonpartisan city elections, voting to forgo changes in a system of selecting municipal officials that has been in place for nearly a century. It was a stinging defeat for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who had invested millions of his own fortune in a campaign
title: THE 2003 ELECTION: CITY CHARTER; CITY VOTES DOWN AN EFFORT TO END PARTY PRIMARIES

body: ''Ben lives at 340 Ocean Parkway. Where does Ben vote?'' Charles Brickous, a retired chemist from Crown Heights, Brooklyn, threw that question out to a classroom filled with an unusual assortment of students -- retirees, political party activists and random other city residents -- who had gathered in a musty Brooklyn back office for what might be
title: This Time, Actually Helping Voters; Remedial Class Tries to Improve Poll Workers' Performance

body: The police were seeking a 25-year-old fugitive yesterday who they said strangled a Brooklyn man and who is also being sought for questioning by the police in Buffalo for a killing there. The police described the fugitive, Mickey Cass, as a drifter who had befriended the Brooklyn man, Vincent Neto-Dambrova, 27, and stuffed him into an apartment
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fugitive Sought In 2 Killings

body: A woman who died after being found unconscious on a sidewalk in Kensington Gardens on Wednesday had been beaten by her husband, the police said. The husband, Alejandro Dominiques, 34, was arrested on murder charges. The dead woman, Barbara Dominiques, 34, had never reported any domestic abuse, the police said. They said she was beaten while leaving
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Beaten Woman Dies

body: Stephanie Elizabeth Buchanan and Jeremy Micah Creelan were married yesterday at the home of Rachel O'Hare, a sister of the bride, in Annapolis, Md. Judge Denise L. Cote of the Federal District Court in New York officiated. Ms. Buchanan, 37, is keeping her name. She is the director of policy and fund-raising at Working Today, a nonprofit labor
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Stephanie Buchanan, Jeremy Creelan

body: EVEN if you think you know New York -- and no one truly does, not in its entirety, vast and varied -- an occasional chance to see a part of the city fresh through someone else's eyes is too good to pass up. So the answer was an eager yes when the offer came to join a bunch of newly minted Brooklyn College professors on a bus tour the other morning
title: NYC; Brooklyn, A Rich Stew Tasted Anew

body: It was the last place one would have expected to find a Navy Seal, but there stood Petty Officer Chris Berman, chiseled and tan in camouflage fatigues, the lone man for miles in a room teeming with romance-novel enthusiasts. Stationed behind a table, an advancing army of giddy, bright-eyed women before him, he might have inspired doubts as to
title: 'Romance Novels,' She Said Adoringly; With Trembling Hand, She Reached Out and Caressed the Autograph

body: GROWING up in Flatbush, Brooklyn, Jaime I. McKenzie learned to pray, to plead and to please a crowd. There were 12 children in his family (he was No. 11) and they shared one television. On Sundays everyone attended Mass together around the corner at St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church. To get out of that, family members said, you
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS: VOWS; Monique Brown and Jaime McKenzie

body: New West Side Greenmarket Through Dec. 20, a new Greenmarket will operate on Saturdays on the Upper West Side, in the triangle from 65th to 66th Street at Broadway and Columbus Avenue, with 10 farmers and other food producers selling their wares. It replaces, in a small way, the Greenmarket at Verdi Square, Broadway at 72nd Street, which was
title: CALENDAR

body: Like his fellow New Yorkers, Brian Stites woke yesterday to more of the same: rain. The sun had escaped New York's skies once again. So Mr. Stites, a painter from Hell's Kitchen, settled for a 10-minute visit with the next closest thing -- a tanning salon. ''By this point in the summer I'm used to having a nice tan,'' said Mr. Stites, 26. ''This is
title: Rain Dates, Lots of Them; With Gray Skies Above, Life Is Stuck Indoors

body: MANHATTAN LOWER EAST SIDE $225,000 475 Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 850-sq.-ft. co-op in a postwar building; attended lobby; windowed eat-in kitchen, 2 walk-in closets, new windows, balcony, 2 exposures, Williamsburg Bridge view; maintenance $483, 26% tax-deductible; listed at $225,000, 1 week on market (broker: Bellmarc Realty)
title: RESIDENTIAL SALES

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement. MANHATTAN GREENWICH VILLAGE $1.52 million 48 Mercer Street 2-bedroom, 3-bath, 2,500-sq.-ft. condo in a renovated prewar loft building; keyed elevator, renovated kitchen
title: Residential Sales

body: A woman stabbed her husband to death early yesterday in Brooklyn, the police said, in one of five killings in the city in a 24-hour period. The other four victims were shot, and six other people were wounded in shootings during what seemed to be a brief spike in gun violence on a warm spring night. While major crime in the city is down more than 8
title: 5 Are Killed In 24 Hours As Violence Spikes in City

body: IN Kansas you can find yourself a long way from anywhere, and Second Lt. John Eichkorn of the state Highway Patrol wasn't happy when his cars used to break down, stranding him far from help in freezing cold. ''I had batteries, alternators, transmissions fail me, all at different times,'' he said. The highway patrol needed more reliability, and so,
title: DRIVING; Used Cars With Police Experience

body: To the Editor: ''Demure Beauties of Old'' (Feb. 23), about Miss Rheingold, omitted a famous winner, Jinx Falkenburg. In the 1940's and 50's, she and her husband, Tex McCrary, had a popular morning radio program called "Tex and Jinx," and were a fixture of the New York airwaves. Reba Shimansky Kensington, Brooklyn
title: Miss Rheingolds To Remember

body: A week that started snowy and turned balmy pulled off a torrential culmination yesterday, as heavy rains pounded the New York area and flooded the region throughout the day. The downpour, which totaled about 1.5 inches according to the National Weather Service, caused major flooding in roads and homes. Authorities issued flash-flood warnings
title: Rain and Snowmelt Cause Wide Flooding

body: SHELLEY HARWAYNE may be ascending the ranks of New York City's staid Department of Education, but a buttoned-down bureaucrat she is not. First, the hair: honey-brown spirals so thick they billow from her head like a cumulus cloud. It is hard to notice anything else, though the gold rings with shimmery old stones -- two per hand -- might catch your
title: PUBLIC LIVES; A School Shake-Up Winner With a Big Challenge

body: Between sobs and prayers, family members struggled yesterday to understand why 13-year-old Randy Carlote died while doing what he loved best -- playing baseball. Randy had shown up at Ditmas Junior High School in Kensington, Brooklyn, on Saturday two hours early for tryouts for a baseball team run by the Youth Service League, a community group, his
title: Tears and Questions After Boy's Fatal Collapse at School

body: Julie Cheit Ross and Mark Paul Ladner were married on Wednesday. Judge Barrington D. Parker Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in White Plains performed the ceremony at M Studio, a loft space in New York. Ms. Ross, 44, is keeping her name. She was until June 2001 a director of investment banking in New York at UBS
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Julie Ross, Mark Ladner
